attributes.action: Include funding for more school gardens in the 2020-21 school building programme
attributes.background: Ideally all schools should have a garden for health, systems learning, emotional & intellectual development, environmental resilience & sustainable work opportunities. Adapt a corner of a playground/sports field/car park to enable development of school curricula & fresh food for local communities.
attributes.additional_details: We know from decades of research globally that outdoor learning & 'garden school' pedgagogies are extremely beneficial for healthy development of children & youth, as well as for lifelong learning & health. We know from climate research that we urgently need to increase urban green space & protect biological diversity in our environment-locally, nationally & globally. Additionally, we know sustainable agricultural practices & food chains increase the resilience of local economies. A win-win.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Make VAT on Second Hand clothing zero rated
attributes.background: Second hand clothing needs to be ZERO VAT rated if the used clothing market is to be able to compete fairly against fast fashion. Vintage/Second Hand clothing stores are having to charge their customers 20% VAT on used items that originally had VAT paid on them. Help make sustainable, affordable.
attributes.additional_details: Our daily feedback is that consumers, whom would like to shop sustainably, are being forced to buy from fast fashion brands as they can’t afford to shop at vintage/second hand shops. Zero VAT on second hand clothing, as it is on children's clothes, would make used clothing affordable and accessible to everyday customers. Wholesalers could also pass on these savings to smaller stores who aren’t VAT registered themselves, allowing the whole sustainable clothing market to compete with fast fashion.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Reallocate funds for Roads & HS2 to shared pedestrian & cycle paths
attributes.background:
The Government should invest in the creation of dual cycle & pedestrian paths to encourage sustainable & active travel, and which could aid social distancing in public spaces. 

Economic cases for road projects & HS2 were based on increased use, but coronavirus has transformed IT use for work etc.
attributes.additional_details:
This investment could make social distancing easier & safer, encourage active & sustainable transport, make local public open spaces more accessible & inclusive & usable in all weather conditions. It could start in months, not years, as local authorities Parks and Transport teams may have shelf ready projects to create away from road networks in Singapore's Park Connector Networks style, & should stimulate the economy

Increasing road & rail use is potentially less likely with the covid changes to business.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Make any bailouts for UK airlines conditional on reducing emissions
attributes.background: The government needs to make UK airlines reduce carbon emissions as a condition of receiving a bail out to survive the COVID-19 outbreak. Currently the government don’t include international flights in the UK carbon budget, and not enough is being done to reduce emissions from this sector.
attributes.additional_details: The current circumstances present an opportunity to request airlines to reduce their emission intensity, to help the UK conform to the UN Paris Agreement. This needs to include actual commitments to reducing emissions rather than just offsetting. Worse crises than the one we’re living through could happen if we don’t take action to create a sustainable future.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban All Single Use Plastics and Plastic Packaging to Save Our Planet
attributes.background: Ban single use plastics and the unnecessary use of plastic packaging in all businesses, supermarkets, retail, or otherwise, the production of and use. The change needs to start now to force changes to sustainable material. This should help save our planet.
attributes.additional_details: We are already seeing abrupt and potentially irreversible environmental change. Animals and their homes are dying. We are running out of room for anymore plastic wastage. It is in our water, air, fish, land and it has to stop. Mexico, Canada and Germany are already taking steps in this direction. We have a responsibility to do this. Stopping single use plastic and all unnecessary plastic packaging could be a win that could have a vast impact on our sustainability.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Exempt couples from the bans on households mixing in local lockdown areas
attributes.background: Follow Scotland’s example and allow established couples to be exempt from restrictions on households mixing going forwards, regardless whether or not they live on their own.
attributes.additional_details: Throughout the pandemic we have done our part, we have been separated for months and the mental impact has been horrific. This can simply not carry on through winter as spending time outside becomes more unpleasant. It is not sustainable nor is it fair to ask anymore. Let us qualify for a support bubble, regardless of whether we live with other people, or exempt us as Scotland have from bans on households mixing both in private dwellings and indoor public spaces.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Introduce mandatory minimum standards for inclusive product packaging
attributes.background: We want Government to work with Industry, Academia and the Design Sector to enforce minimum inclusive standards for product packaging, similar to Part M of the Building Regulations that govern the accessibility of buildings, to ensure packaging is consistent with the Equality Act.
attributes.additional_details: Attempts to reduce costs and increase shelf-life/durability can make consumer packaging difficult or practically impossible to safely open for those without full ability, undermining protections in the Equality Act and the British Standard on Inclusive Design. Decades of campaigning has failed to elicit significant change in the design and manufacture of consumer packaging. By enforcing minimum standards, Government can support accessibility, sustainability and consumer choice.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Replace self-isolation requirements for school students with daily testing
attributes.background: Exempt students who are identified as a contact of a positive Covid case from the requirement to self-isolate, so they can continue attending school, replacing this with daily rapid lateral flow tests, and only having to isolate if they test positive.
attributes.additional_details: The current isolation rules are having a severe detrimental impact on our children’s education and mental well-being, as well as causing serious financial difficulties for parents having to take repeated time off from work. The current rules are not proportionate or sustainable. Our children need to be able to stay in school.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Ban UK imports of soy not certified as being grown sustainably
attributes.background: The growing of soy beans in environmentally sensitive regions (e.g. the Amazon Rainforest) is helping to fuel deforestation and climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Much of these soy products are exported to the UK for animal feeds, and some for direct human consumption, where alternatives products are available
The UK government has a responsibility to reduce environmental impacts. This includes indirect impact via consumption.
 
Much soy in the UK is used for animal feed (~75% by weight), so its environmental damage is not seen by the consumer. The UK government needs to ban imports of soy where it cannot be certified that its production is not negatively impacting the environment, pushing our production markets to use more environmentally friendly sources of soy or alternatives products altogether.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Make allotment space a legal requirement for new major housing developments.
attributes.background: To look into this matter and ratify it in law to ensure that all developers comply with this as part of their application plans.
attributes.additional_details: Many new housing projects have very small gardens or no outdoor space. Allotments bring communities together of all ages and provide both fresh air and exercise for all ages. They help sustainability and also increase the chances of adults/children eating their five a day. With obesity on the rise this would be a perfect way to help with many issues of mental health and wellbeing. Please make this a law.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Ban the weedkillers aminopyralid and clopyralid due to risk of contamination.
attributes.background: I would like the Gov. to ban these herbicides due to increasing cases of contamination in manure and compost. These herbicides can ruin gardens and allotments for many years as the chemicals persist in manure and compost. My allotment has recently been contaminated, and many crops have failed.
attributes.additional_details: Throughout the Covid-19 Crisis more people than ever have turned to growing their own vegetables. Thus, the "lottery" of possible contamination in manure and compost, whereby whole crops can be lost and gardens and allotments ruined for years, should be mitigated by a ban on the sale of aminopyralid and clopyralid in the UK. If we are to move towards a more sustainable relationship with nature, and a more secure and healthy relationship to our food, such cases of contamination must be avoided.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Create a higher rate of Carer's Allowance for people providing 70+ hours care
attributes.background: People are entitled to Carer’s Allowance of £69.70 a week if they care for someone at least 35 hours a week. Many unpaid carers provide more than 70 hours care a week, and we want the Government to create a higher rate of Carer’s Allowance for people who provide 70 or more hours care a week.
attributes.additional_details: The Government should consult on the appropriate level of this new rate. This could include twice the current rate of Carer's Allowance (£139.40) or treat the 70 hours of care as equivalent to a full working week of 37.5 hours at the hourly minimum wage (£356.25). Caring for 70 hrs a week makes it unlikely to be able to sustain full-time paid employment, so the new rate should reflect this. It should also have an increased or no upper earnings limit, so people can claim no matter what paid work they can do.

departments.name: Department for Work and Pensions

attributes.action: Display environmental impact on all packaging and bags containing plastic
attributes.background: The global plastic problem is only increasing and recycling is not going to solve it on its own.
attributes.additional_details:
All packaging containing plastics including bags should display the message “This product contributes to the destruction of our oceans and this impacts human health”, so people see the environmental impact this packaging creates. 

We need to transition to biodegradable plastics such as hemp. Those who live oblivious to the situation deserve education as well as future generations being given a cleaner planet to live on. I want the government to do this to encourage people to demand sustainable solutions to the plastic problem to be able to hand future generations a better planet, that not only benefits humans but the environment and all other species.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Allow schools to use absence Code X for families at increased risk from Covid.
attributes.background: There is a clear and sustained rise in Covid-19 cases. We now have evidence it is spreading in schools. It is inhumane and cruel to expect families who are at an increased risk of severe Covid-19, or increased SEND/anxiety, to choose between fines/prosecution, risking their health, or deregistering.
attributes.additional_details: There are hundreds of families across the country who are currently being forced to choose between their health, lives and their children's ability to attend school. Where a family has a parent or child who is at an increased risk of severe Covid-19, or where a child has SEND/anxiety preventing them from accessing education due to the transmission risk, it should be open for school leaders to make an informed decision (having considered safeguarding issues) to authorise an absence using code X.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: VAT refunds for SMEs
attributes.background: It is now time for the government to act to save and sustain SMEs businesses. We would like the Chancellor to take the initiative to refund VAT payments back to the businesses.
attributes.additional_details:
To save all the small businesses who are facing ruin of no fault of their own. It’s time to save them and try to get our businesses up and running after the pandemic. In addition the SMEs have contributed significantly to the economy and it is now the government should help them in their hour of need.

SME are struggling to pay their suppliers and have very little surplus and therefore will not get paid whilst  their businesses are closed.

This would have an adverse effect on the wider economy. We need to act now!!

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Remove those from the line of succession whose permanent residence is not the UK
attributes.background: It should be law that anyone who does not reside permanently in the UK should be removed from the line of Succession. If someone chooses to live in another country for a sustained period of time, they should automatically forfeit their claim in the line of Succession.
attributes.additional_details: The succession to the throne is regulated by Parliament, with various conditions imposed on those who are able to be in the line of Succession. It is not right that someone who would choose to live abroad could also maintain a claim to the throne of the UK.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Ban the development of Wind Farms within AONBs and National Parks in England
attributes.background: We want a ban to all Wind Farm developments within the environmentally designated AONBs and National Parks. This is due to the onshore wind farms having too much of an impact in terms of Sustainable Development
attributes.additional_details: We must get the principles of Sustainable Development embedded in decision making. Large private owned and public listed companies are exploiting our natural environment. This is wrong and is designed purely for profit. The UK Government should also encourage the devolved administrations to implement similar bans in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Action on Non Exhaust Emissions
attributes.background: The government should adopt as legally binding the World Health Organisation guideline levels  for PM2.5 of 10µg/m³ as an annual mean threshold by 2030.
attributes.additional_details:
The Environment Bill must include legislation on non-exhaust emissions - these are particles from tyres, the road surface and plasticisers. Also known as PM2.5, the major source of these invisible microparticulate
Environmentally friendly and sustainable transport solutions must be found for our busy towns and cities which should include light rail systems.
Parliament should recognise and support in law efforts to clean up the air in our towns and cities.
This should include the provision of a new local transport infrastructure fund to enable transport authorities to develop sustainable clean alternatives including light rail.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Conduct an urgent review for the long-term care of the elderly
attributes.background: The 21st century is the century of the ageing society. The current care system does not support the long term care of the elderly. Do all politicians understand the value of high-quality care? What will it take to get social care as a top priority for government?
attributes.additional_details: Does the government not have a duty of care for the older population as they are likely to be the survivors of medicines which have provided them with a life line?  That life should have a quality of life associated with it and not just an existence.  We need to see continued and increased investment in social care by the government to ensure a sustainable system fit for the 21st Century.  Fact – one in three girls born today will live beyond 100!

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Ban the manufacture and sale of dog waste bags not made of plant-based material
attributes.background: Ban the manufacture and sale of plastic (including degradable) dog waste bags to reduce use of petroleum and to cut CO2 emissions and plastic pollution.
attributes.additional_details:
Millions of dog waste bags are thrown away every day. Some into trees!

The vast majority are made of plastic, and are not recyclable by their use. Even degradable plastic uses petroleum products and degrades to form CO2. 

There's a clear strategy by the vendors of the degradable bags to make them seem environmentally friendly as people don't appreciate they help cause global warming. 

Plant-based bags (e.g. corn starch) are sustainable and non-polluting. We already use them as food waste bags.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase requirements and support for renewable energy for domestic property
attributes.background: Legislate that all new buildings should have at least one renewable energy source & increase support to encourage & assist renewable energy to be taken up by existing home owners.
attributes.additional_details: Harnessing the sun and the wind is sustainable energy. It is more difficult to convert and adapt buildings already built and with massive building programs already taking place, very few have solar panels, ground source heat pumps or any other renewable energy. The Government should take steps to address this before it’s too late.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Rewild 1/3 of UK waters and 1/3 of UK land
attributes.background: The Government should commit to rewilding 1/3 of our national waters and 1/3 of the UKs land. These reserves would be protected from any fishing, forestry and any industry.
attributes.additional_details: We have not yet halted biodiversity and habitat loss. The country and our waters must become sustainable, the sooner we reach this balance the stronger our country will be and the less suffering and global destruction will occur. We could be a world leader on biodiversity and fighting climate change.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Include the harmful environmental impact of plastic waste on the curriculum
attributes.background:
Introduce the harmful environmental effects of plastic waste to the curriculum of schools and colleges to ensure that pupils have in-depth understanding of environmental issues caused by plastic.
35 million plastic bottles are used each day in Britain, and unfortunately less than half are recycled
attributes.additional_details:
Todays society relies on throw away plastic, it is harming the only planet suitable for human life, I believe if people are taught what this material is doing to the earth, it will change their behaviour into a more sustainable, eco friendly lifestyle and will pass on their knowledge onto others.
The problem currently is most people don’t realise how serious this situation is, or are ignorant to it.
The more people learn about this topic, the better it will be for the future of the human race.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Ban the sale of plastic manual toothbrushes in the UK by 2025.
attributes.background: We would like the government to ban the sale of manual plastic toothbrushes in the UK from 2025. Manual plastic toothbrushes are a prolific example of harmful plastic waste, and there are already a roster of viable alternatives on the market for industry to move forward with.
attributes.additional_details: Around 4.7 billion plastic manual toothbrushes are made each year. Each one of these is non-biodegradable. Even after 1000 years in landfill, these will reduce to smaller micro-plastics which are still dangerous to us and our wildlife. There are already viable alternatives, perhaps the most widely used being bamboo compostable toothbrushes. Bamboo suits well as it is quick growing and a sustainable wood to use in these quantities. We have proven that toothbrushes do not need to be harmful.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Reverse the decision to merge DFID with the FCO
attributes.background: On 16 June PM Boris Johnson announced his plans to merge the Department for International Development (DFID) with the Foreign & Commonwealth Office (FCO). The goal of DFID is and always has been to promote equality and sustainable development, and to eliminate world poverty. It should remain intact.
attributes.additional_details: DFID is one of the best performing departments in Government and a soft power asset for Britain. It works to save lives, fight climate change, and achieve gender equality. To lead the global fight against poverty and corruption, we must continue to provide the world's most vulnerable with essential support. Plus, merging the two departments will cost millions. We are in the midst of a global pandemic that should be taking priority. This is not the time to dissolve a vital Government Department.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Require Supermarkets, Restaurants and other Retailers to Donate Food Waste
attributes.background: In France, grocery stores and supermarkets must donate unsold food to charity; the UK wastes this food, despite 14.5 million of its residents living in poverty.
attributes.additional_details:
Much of this food is wasted before it even reaches its best before date when the product has not spoiled and is still completely edible.
 
In 2018, the UK produced around 9.5 million tonnes of food waste. The only way we can stop this is by taking action.
 
Community fridges and food banks could sustainably redistribute food waste to those who need OR want it. As well as tackling food poverty, reducing food waste would reduce carbon emissions. About 6-8% of global human-induced emissions could be reduced if we stop food waste.
 
This is not just a social concern, it’s an environmental one.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase required teaching on climate change in the national curriculum
attributes.background: We want the Government to require 33 hours of climate education each school year, woven through all subjects on our national curriculum. This should help people better understand, adapt to and address the impact of climate change, from an early age.
attributes.additional_details:
The Peoples' Climate Vote found that 64% of people believe we are in a climate emergency. More action is needed. Part of the UN's Sustainable Development Goal for education is that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development.
 
We are making progress by introducing a Natural History GCSE, however providing a solid grounding in environmental awareness from age 4-18 is essential to educate and empower young people to take effective action. We must invest in further climate education to help meet the UKs net zero goals.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Make it illegal to manufacture or sell products using non-recyclable plastic
attributes.background: I want to see a safe sustainable future, but man-made products such as plastic are causing enormous damage to the environment. While many products now use recycled plastic a large amount of products contains virgin plastic which uses oil.
attributes.additional_details: By reducing the amount of oil we use we be able to reduce damage to the environment. To help achieve this the Government should ban the manufacture and sale of products using non-recyclable plastic. All companies will need to use recycled plastic in their products. This will help because recycling is helping the environment.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make it easier for people to build low impact housing
attributes.background: Update planning laws to allow for environmentally friendly, low impact and sustainable homes to be built in England more easily, thus letting people live with less impact on the environment. This has been done with the one planet development policy in Wales and the crofting legislation in Scotland.
attributes.additional_details: The current housing crisis and worsening climate crisis are both problems facing us currently. The movement for low impact and sustainable dwellings, like those allowed by the Welsh one planet development policy and Scottish Crofting Commission are helping to reduce both of these issues. The current, outdated legislation in England makes it difficult to build low impact dwellings with sustainable materials, ultimately resulting in environmental damage and a potentiation of the housing crisis

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Set up a National Nature Service to tackle the climate and unemployment crisis
attributes.background: With Government at all levels of the UK recently declaring ecological and climate emergencies and with the Covid-19 pandemic now expected to increase unemployment to levels not seen in a generation. I believe the time is right for a Government funded employment and training National Nature Service.
attributes.additional_details:
Create a well funded employment programme offering living wage levels for quality training, education and work in conservation. It is vital that people of all ages must be given the option to join the service and are not forced. 
The Service would work in partnership with conservation NGO's, Government Agencies and National Park Authorities.
Report after report bear witness to the destruction of the UK's natural world and we must take action to make a green and sustainable recovery a reality.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Preserve diverse and mature woodlands in view of climate change.
attributes.background: To review policies concerning 'woodland management', in particular the PAWs restoration document in view of  the effects of climate change.
attributes.additional_details: The large scale removal of mature native and established none-native tree species from our mixed woodlands is not sustainable.  Woodland regeneration is slow and uncertain. Mature trees including conifer varieties have become established and play a vital role in the formation of twenty first century woodlands. I would ask the government to further protect existing woodlands in all their diversity for the benefit of people and wildlife.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Abolish police use of Tasers
attributes.background: Police use of Tasers is increasing at a worrying rate. We call for the Government to put an immediate end to police use of Conducted Energy Devices (i.e. Tasers), given their capacity to inflict (sometimes fatal and life-changing) injury.
attributes.additional_details: In England & Wales, police Taser use has increased by more than 500% over the last decade. Since 2003, at least 18 people have died after Tasers were used against them, and many more have sustained serious trauma/injury. Home Office data also reveals that Tasers are used in racially disproportionate ways, and too often used against children and vulnerable adults, particularly those experiencing mental health issues.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Increase funding for Care Services
attributes.background: Increase care funding, particularly for Domiciliary Care, as carers are leaving the sector due to the cost of living.
attributes.additional_details: Councils are not prepared to help and the markets are not sustainable. Vulnerable Adults are at risk.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Require recycling systems in NHS clinical areas for plastic healthcare waste
attributes.background: Across the NHS, there are no means of sustainably disposing of uncontaminated plastic clinical waste (namely sterile packaging). This means that huge quantities of potentially recyclable plastic are disposed of daily and sent to landfills or incinerators, greatly harming our environment.
attributes.additional_details: There are no formal recycling plans or mechanisms in place across NHS clinical environments, which we believe is wholly unsustainable. We want to have this changed and for recycling to be the new norm when it comes to uncontaminated clinical and non-clinical waste in the healthcare industry. See www.recycle-health.org”

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Invest in coal, oil, gas and nuclear to help achieve energy independence
attributes.background: To help maintain global supply following Russian sanctions but to ensure energy independence medium term, the Government should invest immediately in reopening oil and gas fields in the North Sea and elsewhere, coalfields, and nuclear power plants.
attributes.additional_details:
Whilst we should continue to invest in reducing need for oil and gas we have to accept we are not there yet.

This should help ensure our short and medium term energy independence whilst we continue to invest in sustainable, but independent, alternatives.

Support for nuclear energy would help the whole country be electrically powered through cheap, clean fuel to help ensure a clean and independent future.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban imports of oil from Nigeria pending human rights and sustainability reviews
attributes.background: The Government should consider a UK ban on oil imports from Nigeria, pending a full review of reported human rights abuses, so that there is no risk of revenue from UK imports being used to finance activities which breach human rights, and of the sustainability of the oil industry.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK has a unique historic and contemporary commercial interest in Nigeria. And a responsibility to intervene regarding concerns about human rights and sustainability.
The fossil fuel industry feeds massive biodiversity loss, pollution, degradation of land and water resources.
 
The Government should consider a full ban on oil exports from Nigeria until full reviews of reported human rights abuses and sustainability of the oil industry has been completed.
 
An urgent targeted response is required.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Abolish the Upper Earnings Limit for National Insurance
attributes.background: To remove the Upper Earnings Limit in employee National Insurance contributions which, at the moment means that those on £50,000 pa pay only 2% employee NI on their income above that level.
attributes.additional_details:
Abolishing the Upper Earnings Limit should increase National Insurance revenue by billions of pounds a year.
 
Today, someone earning £1 million pays, in effect, 2,4% of gross income on employer NI, whilst someone on £25k pays 7.4%, on £50k 9.7%. An MP pays 6.7% on basic MP salary.

Abolition of the UEL would make contributions more equitable, ensure improved funding the NI system on a sustained basis, and reflect ability to pay.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Add sustainability to the National Curriculum
attributes.background: I would like the government to add a sustainability to the national curriculum and start teaching how our actions and decisions impact the world.
attributes.additional_details:
We are at a critical point in the world with CO2 levels at a record high, over fishing killing our seas, deforestation occurring at an alarming rate, global warming causing terrifying conditions globally.

Education is vital to ensure people support the positive actions towards a better future within the near future. Without education the nation will not actively support the changes required!

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Ban plastic fishing nets in UK waters.
attributes.background: Plastic fishing gear discarded from vessels are polluting our seas and strangling wildlife. A truly biodegradable alternative needs to be rediscovered. Our oceans are a dumping ground for plastic and other rubbish; plastic fishing nets, ropes and other gear form a significant part of that pollution.
attributes.additional_details: Get plastic out of the sea, and stop any more unnecessary plastic waste including nets going into the seas. Persuade the fishing industry that fishing cannot be sustained with so much plastic waste in our oceans, including continued discarding of nets straggling and killing sea creatures.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Add a 'sustainability charge' on meat products to cover their environmental cost
attributes.background: Food production accounts for one-quarter of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions and takes up half of the planet’s habitable surface. The mass of animals raised for slaughter on Earth now outweighs wildlife by a factor of 15-to-1. One kilogram of beef needs about 15 thousand litres of water.
attributes.additional_details: By adding a 'sustainability charge' to meat products, this will encourage more conscious meat consumption. With this money going towards tackling climate change and renewable energy resources.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Adopt plans for a common charging cable for all new electronic portable devices
attributes.background: The EU has provisionally agreed that all new portable electronic devices must, by autumn 2024, use a USB Type-C charger, regardless of who makes the devices.  However, the UK government has said that it is not adopting the same plan.
attributes.additional_details: Adopting a common charging cable would make the UK more sustainable, reduce electronic waste and make consumers' lives much easier.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Require warning labels on palm oil products that are not produced sustainably
attributes.background: The Government should require products containing palm oil, where it has not been certified that this has been produced sustainably, to include labels showing the harm palm oil production causes, so consumers are made aware of this.
attributes.additional_details:
Palm oil is a huge contributor to deforestation in tropical climates, areas booming with wildlife, areas which many animals have called home for thousands of years. The deforestation caused by palm oil plantations have had a substantial negative impact on these areas, causing mass death and extinction of the animals living there. in Borneo, dozens orangutans are killed every week due to the production of palm oil.
This needs to end, and this is a start.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Halt the reopening of schools until the NEU's 5 tests are met
attributes.background: In the interests of the safety of school pupils and staff, we the undersigned call upon the Government to halt plans to reopen schools and colleges on 1st June 2020 (or thereafter) until the five tests put forward by the National Education Union have been met.
attributes.additional_details:
We support schools reopening once it is safe. We call open Government to wait until it has fulfilled the NEU's 5 tests:

1: Lower numbers of Covid-19 cases (a sustained downward trend).
2: A national plan for social distancing and appropriate PPE.
3: Testing so schools/colleges don’t become hot spots.
4: A strategy for when a case occurs.
5: Protection for the vulnerable (to work from home).

The tests are set out in full here: https://neu.org.uk/neu-five-tests-government-schools-can-re-open

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Allow carers in full-time education during COVID-19 to claim Carer's Allowance.
attributes.background: Allow carers who are in full-time education, but are now studying and living at their family home during COVID-19, to claim Carer's Allowance as a means by which they can further physically and financially assist their ailing loved ones, whilst also being able to sustain their academic studies.
attributes.additional_details: Under current regulations, Carer's Allowance is only accessible for individuals who are not in full-time education. Under normal circumstances, many of these students would be living away from their family house. However, after COVID-19, many students are staying at their family homes, with many taking up caring responsibilities for their relatives, without much financial support. This can have a significant impact on them being able to physically and financially support their ailing loved ones.

departments.name: Department for Work and Pensions

attributes.action: Make it mandatory to label products as Vegan or Non-Vegan
attributes.background:
Going vegan has been challenging to figure out what products are vegan or not, especially when certain ingredients can be derived from plants or animals.

Having food and toiletries clearly labelled helps to prevent accidentally purchasing a non-vegan product.
attributes.additional_details:
Every day, there are more people considering a vegan diet, but when those people start out, there is this difficulty knowing what products are not vegan, as they are usually difficult to know about without someone telling them first.

Having this label can also help people choose to buy more sustainably sourced foods or toiletries, as using animal derived products has a large carbon footprint.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require employers pay employees for mandatory work breaks
attributes.background: Under employment law employees have a right to an uninterrupted rest break of at least 20 minutes if they work more than six hours a day. Most employers require staff to take this break, or even longer breaks, often without pay, which leaves many employees financially worse off.
attributes.additional_details: Unpaid work breaks is a particular issue for Keyworkers, who were some of those most at risk during the pandemic. For example, most supermarkets don't pay for the break times of their staff. It is not a legal requirement unless stated in their employee contract. Supermarkets have proven to be one of the most profitable and sustainable businesses during these times, yet they do not pay for breaks even though most have had record profits this year. It's time we start paying for these breaks.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Fund weekly veg and fruit boxes for all families and individuals on low income
attributes.background: Obesity is complex encompassing mental health, wealth and accessibility. A healthy nation requires regular and sustainable nutrition. By providing this the Government could reduce hunger, decrease poverty, increase health & wellbeing, reduce inequality and help alleviate the climate crisis.
attributes.additional_details: We're calling for the Government to fund the provision of a weekly Veg & Fruit box to all individuals and families on low income, removing the reliance on and the stigma of using a food bank. The shielding scheme is proof that food can be provided on a national scale with weekly food parcels being delivered up and down the country. We can and should be doing this as a first port of call in the fight against obesity.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce VAT on meat products and stop subsiding animal agriculture
attributes.background: Stop the millions spent on environmentally harmful farming subsidising. Then introduce a value added tax to all animal products.
attributes.additional_details: To help stop the catastrophic effects of the climate crisis, we need to drastically reduce our intake of animal products. Introducing a tax and stopping subsidies would make alternative products more price competitive and pressure already existing brands to move towards a more environmentally sustainable business model.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Create a regulator for licences to play live or recorded music
attributes.background: The Government should create a regulator to oversee the UK music licensing (PPL PRS) and set tariffs and the criteria that determines which music uses are licensable and which are not.
attributes.additional_details: Music licensing is carried out by an independent limited company that sets unregulated tariffs. Businesses that use commercially available music as part of their service (eg. dance & fitness classes) are charged rates that could undermine the viability of their business. Also, we believe the conditions on which uses of music incur a charge are unreasonable. This petition asks Government to establish a regulator to ensure that tariffs and chargeable uses are fair and don’t create a barrier to sustainable business

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Set a legal minimum temperature to be maintained in school classrooms
attributes.background: I would like the government to set a minimum temperature students have to endure in a classroom. Guidance for full opening of schools specifies keeping windows open to allow air to flow naturally because of COVID-19. This has meant classrooms have been getting very cold.
attributes.additional_details: The guidance states all windows in classrooms should be left open to help the natural flow of air and prevent the spread of the virus. The classrooms get far too cold and this means students can't focus and could result in illness from sustained periods of sitting in a cold room for over an hour. Students are currently wearing multiple jumpers and coats in lessons because of the conditions enforced by COVID-19.
